repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Urban Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Urban Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project for Indonesia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was high, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the absence of reform component accompanying public
            investment is likely to result in unsustainable improvement
            and expansion of water supply. The design of any policy,
            program, project or financing arrangements should carefully
            take this into account. The sub-loan agreement (SLA)
            arrangement that focuses only on physical investments may be
            more suitable for PEMDAs and PDAMs with relatively strong
            capacity. The amount of investment should be adjusted
            depending on the management capacities of the PEMDAs and
            PDAMs. Under the decentralized environment wherein PEMDAs
            have more responsibilities in the provision of water supply
            services, the Central Government still continues to play a
            role particularly in initiating sector reforms,
            incentivizing and regulating the performance of PEMDAs.
            While leveraging and collaboration with other programs are
            generally beneficial as these allow projects to generate
            opportunities for expanding financial and technical
            resources and create greater synergy and wider impact, it is
            important to carefully consider and define the timing,
            resources, design and arrangements for collaboration to
            ensure that intended objectives are met.

repnme.cdata!:
Indonesia - Urban Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project : restructuring paper

abstracts.cdata!:
This restructuring paper for the Urban
            Water Supply and Sanitation Project in Indonesia involves
            revision and update to the Results Framework and its key
            performance indicators described in the Project Appraisal
            Document (PAD). This will ensure that a more efficient set
            of indicators are applied during project implementation and
            they are consistently presented in the Performance
            Agreements between Local Governments and their respective
            PDAMs. The project is currently rated as Satisfactory
            towards achievement of its Project Development Objectives
            and overall Implementation Progress is rated as Moderately
            Satisfactory. The proposed changes to be included in this
            restructuring include: (i) revision and update of the
            Results Framework (description and definition of Key
            Performance Indicators to include core indicator and to
            ensure consistency between all project documents); and (ii)
            to correct and update baseline data and targets.

            and Sanitation Project : restructuring paper (Vol. 2) : Data sheet
